	<time class="e-published-date u-meta " datetime="2021-01-08T17:53+0000" data-test="time">

				<div class="articleBodyText section">




<div class="component article-body-text    " data-test="article-body-text">
  
  

	

	
	

	
	



  
  
    <p>Standing in the glaringly white, air conditioned corridors of one of Manaus’ newest hospitals in September, Dr Thales Schincariol insisted that the hard-hit Brazilian city was unlikely to witness a resurgence of Covid-19. </p>
<p>“Studies suggest two thirds of the Manaus was already infected,” the then assistant secretary for health <a href="https://www.telegraph.co.uk/global-health/science-and-disease/brazils-covid-19-epicentre/">told The Telegraph</a>. “We don’t know the exact figure for herd immunity, but because we’ve crossed the 50 per cent mark we don’t expect a second wave.”</p>
<p>Four months later – amid a nationwide surge in Covid – the situation in the sprawling port-city in the heart of the Amazon rainforest resembles the crisis last April and May, when Manaus gained global notoriety as <a href="https://www.telegraph.co.uk/global-health/science-and-disease/brazils-covid-19-epicentre/">images of mass graves lapped the globe</a>. </p>
<p>Hospitals are once again overflowing, with occupancy nearing 100 per cent, and the city reported a record high in new admissions this week. </p>
<p>Meanwhile the ambulance service is fielding an <a href="https://g1.globo.com/am/amazonas/noticia/2021/01/05/samu-opera-no-limite-e-sem-capacidade-para-atender-toda-populacao-de-manaus-afirma-diretor.ghtml" rel="nofollow">“absurdly high” volume of calls</a>; refrigerated containers have been reinstalled outside health facilities to hold the corpses of Covid-19 victims; and the infamous new site cleared last March at Parque Tarumã cemetery is almost full.</p>
  
</div>
</div>
<figure data-js="article-body-image" data-test="article-body-image" class="article-body-image section">





	

	
	

	
	









	
	

	



	
	

		<div class="article-body-image__container">

			
			

			
				
				

	
	
	
	

	
	

	
	

	
	

	
	
	
	
	
	
	


	

	

	

	


	
	

	
	
	<picture class="article-body-image__source  ">

			</span>

</figure>
<div class="articleBodyText section">




<div class="component article-body-text    " data-test="article-body-text">
  
  

	

	
	

	
	



  
  
    <p>“Things are terrible here,” one local photojournalist told The Telegraph. “I’ve been at the hospital for about an hour and I’ve already seen four bodies being taken by funeral service cars.”</p>
<p>In an attempt to stem spiralling infections, the state government last month ordered that all non-essential businesses must close between December 26 and January 10. Then, on Monday, authorities declared a 180-day state of emergency.</p>
<p>“We are adopting all the necessary measures to contribute decisively to the fight against Covid-19, especially at this moment in which the city is registering an increase in cases and, unfortunately, deaths,” Mayor David Almeida said in a statement.</p>
<p>Manaus was always at high risk of ferocious Covid-19 outbreaks. The city has high rates of inequality, with <a href="https://agenciadenoticias.ibge.gov.br/agencia-noticias/2012-agencia-de-noticias/noticias/27728-quase-dois-tercos-das-favelas-estao-a-menos-de-dois-quilometros-de-hospitais">government estimates </a>suggesting that 53 per cent of households live in poor, tightly packed communities. Meanwhile just 12 per cent of people in Manaus have access to a sewage system, according to the Brazil Institute.</p>
  
</div>
</div>
<figure data-js="article-body-image" data-test="article-body-image" class="article-body-image section">





	

	
	

	
	









	
	

	



	
	

		<div class="article-body-image__container">

			
			

			
				
				

	
	
	
	

	
	

	
	

	
	

	
	
	
	
	
	
	


	

	

	

	


	
	

	
	
	<picture class="article-body-image__source  ">

			<source srcset="/content/dam/global-health/2021/01/08/TELEMMGLPICT000241440805_trans_NvBQzQNjv4Bqvrw6jddRn8vAMv8z8p9o_qbUGRr64oRQYaGc1km7Gac.jpeg?imwidth=680" media="( min-width: 768px )"/>

	</picture>

			</span>

</figure>
<div class="articleBodyText section">




<div class="component article-body-text    " data-test="article-body-text">
  
  

	

	
	

	
	



  
  
    <p>Add to that list an already stretched healthcare system and you have a “perfect storm”, said Lucas Ferrante, an ecological epidemiologist at the National Institute for Research in Amazonia (INPA) in Manaus. While Brazil has an average of 2.1 doctors per 1,000 people, this drops to 1.2 in Amazonas state.</p>
<p>These were among the factors that caught the city off-guard last year. The first case was detected on March 13; by the end of April weekly excess deaths stood at 815 – a 325 per cent increase compared to the same period in 2019. </p>
<p>Dr Schincariol, who resigned from his position in October, was far from alone in hoping that the brutality of that first outbreak would protect the city from a second. </p>
<p>Last summer a study led by the University of São Paulo’s Institute of Tropical Medicine, which tested recent blood bank donations for Sars-Cov-2 antibodies, found the city had an “unusually high” infection rate.</p>
  
</div>
</div>
<div class="html-embed section" data-test="html-embed">








	<span></span>
	<aside id="e3dd3d81-e69e-4371-a0f9-a4131aa34407" data-data-uri="https://particle-api.eip.telegraph.co.uk/v2/particles/e3dd3d81-e69e-4371-a0f9-a4131aa34407" data-html-uri="https://cf-particle-html.eip.telegraph.co.uk/e3dd3d81-e69e-4371-a0f9-a4131aa34407.html" class="tmg-particle breakout-box" data-reg-required="false" data-reg-redirect="" data-sub-required="false" data-sub-redirect="" data-widget-type="breakout-box" data-widget-title="A perfect storm: How did one city lose so many to Covid-19?" data-widget-size="responsive" data-widget-static="false" data-expandable="true" data-embeddable="true"><a title="A perfect storm: How did one city lose so many to Covid-19?" data-cke-saved-href="https://cf-particle-html.eip.telegraph.co.uk/e3dd3d81-e69e-4371-a0f9-a4131aa34407.html" href="https://cf-particle-html.eip.telegraph.co.uk/e3dd3d81-e69e-4371-a0f9-a4131aa34407.html">A perfect storm: How did one city lose so many to Covid-19?</a></aside><script src="https://cf.eip.telegraph.co.uk/particle-embed/js/particle.js" defer></script>


</div>
<div class="articleBodyText section">




<div class="component article-body-text    " data-test="article-body-text">
  
  

	

	
	

	
	



  
  
    <p style="">From May to August between 44 and 66 per cent of people contracted Covid-19. According to the study “herd immunity played a significant role” in declining cases in August – the virus ran out of people to infect. </p>
<p style="">An updated version of that study, <a href="https://science.sciencemag.org/content/early/2020/12/07/science.abe9728" rel="nofollow" style="">now published in Science</a>, concluded that 76 per cent of the population in Manaus became infected with Sars-Cov-2 between March and October - compared to 29 per cent in São Paulo.</p>
<p style="">The report's authors have warned that the findings are a stark illustration of what can happen if an outbreak is unmitigated. </p>
<p style="">“Some people think that the virus will go away immediately once infections reach a herd immunity level,” Prof Ester Sabino, an immunologist at University of São Paulo, the lead researcher of the study, <a href="https://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2020/12/24/949799132/the-worst-of-covid-should-be-over-for-one-hard-hit-brazilian-city-but-its-not">told NPR</a>. “But for a while, it just moves slower, continuing to kill people.”</p>
<p style="">However, while there is a general consensus among experts that the state's official toll is an undercount due to patchy testing - Amazonas, home to some 4 million people, has officially reported 208,798 cases and 5,546 deaths - other experts are cautious about the paper's results.</p>
  
</div>
</div>
<figure data-js="article-body-image" data-test="article-body-image" class="article-body-image section">





	

	
	

	
	









	
	

	



	
	

		<div class="article-body-image__container">

			
			

			
				
				

	
	
	
	

	
	

	
	

	
	

	
	
	
	
	
	
	


	

	

	

	


	
	

	
	
	<picture class="article-body-image__source  ">

			<source srcset="/content/dam/global-health/2021/01/08/TELEMMGLPICT000248048508_trans_NvBQzQNjv4BqaRL1kC4G7DT9ZsZm6Pe3PehAFAI_f6ud569StXyOKH0.jpeg?imwidth=680" media="( min-width: 768px )"/>

	</picture>




			

			
			

		</div>

				Nurses transport a patient infected with coronavirus to the 28 de Agosto Hospital in Manaus as pressure on the ambulance service, SAMU, reaches new heights
			</span>
		

		
		
			<span class="e-caption__credit" data-test="credit">

			</span>
		
	</figcaption>



	

	
	


</figure>
<div class="articleBodyText section">




<div class="component article-body-text    " data-test="article-body-text">
  
  

	

	
	

	
	



  
  
    <p style="">Many argue it is difficult to extrapolate conclusions about the broader population from studies testing a subset of people, warning that the work must be “well-interpreted”.</p>
<p style="">Other studies have also suggested that the infection rate in the city's first wave was below the herd-immunity threshold. Last June a seroprevalence survey <a href="https://www.thelancet.com/journals/langlo/article/PIIS2214-109X(20)30387-9/fulltext#seccestitle10" rel="nofollow">published in the Lancet</a> found the Amazonas region was among the worst hit in Brazil - but the highest antibody rate recorded remained around 25 per cent. </p>
<p>Mr Ferrante added that estimates from INPA suggest “it is more plausible that less than 50 per cent of the population has had contact with Sars-Cov-2” in Manaus - meaning at least half of the population are still susceptible to the virus. </p>
<p style="">He said he believed suggestions of herd immunity were seized by the authorities last autumn, contributing to a <a href="https://www.telegraph.co.uk/global-health/science-and-disease/brazils-covid-19-epicentre/">complacent attitude across the city</a>, from decision-makers in government to fishmongers at the downtown market. </p>
  
</div>
</div>
<figure data-js="article-body-image" data-test="article-body-image" class="article-body-image section">





	

	
	

	
	









	
	

	



	
	

		<div class="article-body-image__container">

			
			

			
				
				

	
	
	
	

	
	

	
	

	
	

	
	
	
	
	
	
	


	

	

	

	


	
	

	
	
	<picture class="article-body-image__source  ">

			<source srcset="/content/dam/global-health/2021/01/08/TELEMMGLPICT000241443312_trans_NvBQzQNjv4BqpVlberWd9EgFPZtcLiMQfyf2A9a6I9YchsjMeADBa08.jpeg?imwidth=480" media="( min-width: 350px )"/>

	</picture>




			

			
			

		</div>

			<span data-test="caption">
				The market in central Manaus, which has remained open throughout the pandemic.
			</span>
		

		
		
			<span class="e-caption__credit" data-test="credit">

			</span>
		
	</figcaption>



	

	
	


</figure>
<div class="articleBodyText section">




<div class="component article-body-text    " data-test="article-body-text">
  
  

	

	
	

	
	



  
  
    <p>“It is evident that political neglect led Manaus to a second wave of Covid-19,” Mr Ferrante told the Telegraph this week. “We reached a number of hospitalisations above the first wave in April and May. The current scenario completely overturns this idea of herd immunity.”</p>
<p>Across Brazil - which surpassed the grim milestone of 200,000 fatalities this week - there are wider concerns that the Covid threat is not being taken seriously, with New Year’s Eve bringing an explosion of <a href="https://www.telegraph.co.uk/travel/news/postcard-brazil-party-loving-residents-fighting-calls-another/">parties egged on by Jair Bolsonaro’s administration</a>. </p>
<p>The President, who enjoys substantial support in Manaus, has repeatedly downplayed Covid as “little flu”. Just before Christmas, tourism minister Gilson Machado told radio station Jovem Pan that gatherings of up to 300 people were perfectly acceptable.</p>
<p style="">Vanda Ortega, a volunteer nurse in Manaus’ Community of Indigenous Nations, <a href="https://apnews.com/article/pandemics-brazil-rio-de-janeiro-coronavirus-pandemic-sao-paulo-d76bc225c39db5822ce5cbfb84defbc4">told the Associated Press</a> this week that the city had also adopted a hands-off approach towards mitigation policies. </p>
<p>During November, local elections saw large rallies and long lines of voters. “Then we had the holiday season, with a lot of secret parties,” she said. “We live in an area where rich people have cabins. They have parties every week.”</p>
  
</div>
</div>
<div class="html-embed section" data-test="html-embed">








	<span></span>
	<aside id="63036507-e7d8-4ff5-8f52-0c83a3e5dcb1" data-data-uri="https://particle-api.eip.telegraph.co.uk/v2/particles/63036507-e7d8-4ff5-8f52-0c83a3e5dcb1" data-html-uri="https://cf-particle-html.eip.telegraph.co.uk/63036507-e7d8-4ff5-8f52-0c83a3e5dcb1.html" class="tmg-particle embed" data-reg-required="false" data-reg-redirect="" data-sub-required="false" data-sub-redirect="" data-widget-type="embed" data-widget-title="Coronavirus Brazil Spotlight Chart - Cases default" data-widget-size="responsive" data-widget-static="false" data-expandable="false" data-embeddable="true"><a title="Coronavirus Brazil Spotlight Chart - Cases default" data-cke-saved-href="https://cf-particle-html.eip.telegraph.co.uk/63036507-e7d8-4ff5-8f52-0c83a3e5dcb1.html" href="https://cf-particle-html.eip.telegraph.co.uk/63036507-e7d8-4ff5-8f52-0c83a3e5dcb1.html">Coronavirus Brazil Spotlight Chart - Cases default</a></aside><script src="https://cf.eip.telegraph.co.uk/particle-embed/js/particle.js" defer></script>


</div>
<div class="articleBodyText section">




<div class="component article-body-text    " data-test="article-body-text">
  
  

	

	
	

	
	



  
  
    <p>In response to suggestions of complacency, the Amazonas state government insisted that they have been working “since October 2020” on a contingency plan for a Covid resurgence. </p>
<p style="">“In two months, the Government of Amazonas increased the offer of exclusive beds for Covid-19 in the state health system by 141 per cent. In the ICU, the increase in beds was 139 per cent,” a spokesperson told the Telegraph. </p>
<p style="">But for Mr Ferrante, the renewed crisis is a stark warning to the world to continue to take the virus seriously until mass vaccination has been carried out - in Brazil, the government is yet to unveil a clear timeline. </p>
<p>“The world must not believe in naturally-acquired herd immunity, and Manaus has never been and will never be an example,” Mr Ferrante said. </p>
<p><strong><em>Protect yourself and your family by learning more about <a href="https://www.telegraph.co.uk/global-health/">Global Health Security</a></em></strong></p>

readabilityObject.title: Hopes of 'herd immunity' wane in Manaus as city declares state of emergency to curb Covid resurgence
readabilityObject.content:
Hospitals and cemeteries are again overwhelmed, resembling the brutal outbreak last April. It comes as Brazil's death toll hits 200,000

Global Health Security Reporter

08 January 2021 5:53pm GMT

Standing in the glaringly white, air conditioned corridors of one of Manaus’ newest hospitals in September, Dr Thales Schincariol insisted that the hard-hit Brazilian city was unlikely to witness a resurgence of Covid-19. 

“Studies suggest two thirds of the Manaus was already infected,” the then assistant secretary for health told The Telegraph. “We don’t know the exact figure for herd immunity, but because we’ve crossed the 50 per cent mark we don’t expect a second wave.”

Four months later – amid a nationwide surge in Covid – the situation in the sprawling port-city in the heart of the Amazon rainforest resembles the crisis last April and May, when Manaus gained global notoriety as images of mass graves lapped the globe. 

Hospitals are once again overflowing, with occupancy nearing 100 per cent, and the city reported a record high in new admissions this week. 

Meanwhile the ambulance service is fielding an “absurdly high” volume of calls; refrigerated containers have been reinstalled outside health facilities to hold the corpses of Covid-19 victims; and the infamous new site cleared last March at Parque Tarumã cemetery is almost full.

“Things are terrible here,” one local photojournalist told The Telegraph. “I’ve been at the hospital for about an hour and I’ve already seen four bodies being taken by funeral service cars.”

In an attempt to stem spiralling infections, the state government last month ordered that all non-essential businesses must close between December 26 and January 10. Then, on Monday, authorities declared a 180-day state of emergency.

“We are adopting all the necessary measures to contribute decisively to the fight against Covid-19, especially at this moment in which the city is registering an increase in cases and, unfortunately, deaths,” Mayor David Almeida said in a statement.

Manaus was always at high risk of ferocious Covid-19 outbreaks. The city has high rates of inequality, with government estimates suggesting that 53 per cent of households live in poor, tightly packed communities. Meanwhile just 12 per cent of people in Manaus have access to a sewage system, according to the Brazil Institute.

Add to that list an already stretched healthcare system and you have a “perfect storm”, said Lucas Ferrante, an ecological epidemiologist at the National Institute for Research in Amazonia (INPA) in Manaus. While Brazil has an average of 2.1 doctors per 1,000 people, this drops to 1.2 in Amazonas state.

These were among the factors that caught the city off-guard last year. The first case was detected on March 13; by the end of April weekly excess deaths stood at 815 – a 325 per cent increase compared to the same period in 2019. 

Dr Schincariol, who resigned from his position in October, was far from alone in hoping that the brutality of that first outbreak would protect the city from a second. 

Last summer a study led by the University of São Paulo’s Institute of Tropical Medicine, which tested recent blood bank donations for Sars-Cov-2 antibodies, found the city had an “unusually high” infection rate.

From May to August between 44 and 66 per cent of people contracted Covid-19. According to the study “herd immunity played a significant role” in declining cases in August – the virus ran out of people to infect. 

An updated version of that study, now published in Science, concluded that 76 per cent of the population in Manaus became infected with Sars-Cov-2 between March and October - compared to 29 per cent in São Paulo.

The report's authors have warned that the findings are a stark illustration of what can happen if an outbreak is unmitigated. 

“Some people think that the virus will go away immediately once infections reach a herd immunity level,” Prof Ester Sabino, an immunologist at University of São Paulo, the lead researcher of the study, told NPR. “But for a while, it just moves slower, continuing to kill people.”

However, while there is a general consensus among experts that the state's official toll is an undercount due to patchy testing - Amazonas, home to some 4 million people, has officially reported 208,798 cases and 5,546 deaths - other experts are cautious about the paper's results.

Many argue it is difficult to extrapolate conclusions about the broader population from studies testing a subset of people, warning that the work must be “well-interpreted”.

Other studies have also suggested that the infection rate in the city's first wave was below the herd-immunity threshold. Last June a seroprevalence survey published in the Lancet found the Amazonas region was among the worst hit in Brazil - but the highest antibody rate recorded remained around 25 per cent. 

Mr Ferrante added that estimates from INPA suggest “it is more plausible that less than 50 per cent of the population has had contact with Sars-Cov-2” in Manaus - meaning at least half of the population are still susceptible to the virus. 

He said he believed suggestions of herd immunity were seized by the authorities last autumn, contributing to a complacent attitude across the city, from decision-makers in government to fishmongers at the downtown market. 

“It is evident that political neglect led Manaus to a second wave of Covid-19,” Mr Ferrante told the Telegraph this week. “We reached a number of hospitalisations above the first wave in April and May. The current scenario completely overturns this idea of herd immunity.”

Across Brazil - which surpassed the grim milestone of 200,000 fatalities this week - there are wider concerns that the Covid threat is not being taken seriously, with New Year’s Eve bringing an explosion of parties egged on by Jair Bolsonaro’s administration. 

The President, who enjoys substantial support in Manaus, has repeatedly downplayed Covid as “little flu”. Just before Christmas, tourism minister Gilson Machado told radio station Jovem Pan that gatherings of up to 300 people were perfectly acceptable.

Vanda Ortega, a volunteer nurse in Manaus’ Community of Indigenous Nations, told the Associated Press this week that the city had also adopted a hands-off approach towards mitigation policies. 

During November, local elections saw large rallies and long lines of voters. “Then we had the holiday season, with a lot of secret parties,” she said. “We live in an area where rich people have cabins. They have parties every week.”

In response to suggestions of complacency, the Amazonas state government insisted that they have been working “since October 2020” on a contingency plan for a Covid resurgence. 

“In two months, the Government of Amazonas increased the offer of exclusive beds for Covid-19 in the state health system by 141 per cent. In the ICU, the increase in beds was 139 per cent,” a spokesperson told the Telegraph. 

But for Mr Ferrante, the renewed crisis is a stark warning to the world to continue to take the virus seriously until mass vaccination has been carried out - in Brazil, the government is yet to unveil a clear timeline. 

“The world must not believe in naturally-acquired herd immunity, and Manaus has never been and will never be an example,” Mr Ferrante said. 

Protect yourself and your family by learning more about Global Health Security
